venue.title: The Station
venue.blurb: The old railroad station at Weaver and Main streets has been an anchor of Carrboro–Chapel Hill nightlife for years. It's been a mainstay to the music culture, from open mic nights to touring bands' sets — it was even the site of a surprise performance by The Roots in 2012. After The Station changed hands in 2015, the proximate kitchen at The Southern Rail was reinvented as CrossTies, the only true BBQ joint in Chapel Hill and Carrboro.

venue.title: Cat's Cradle
venue.blurb: Cat's Cradle has hosted almost any band you could name that has toured the Southeast during its long history, from Nirvana to KRS-One. The club has steered and showcased musicians to Chapel Hill and Carrboro for 40 years.

venue.title: The Pour House
venue.blurb: Live music and drinks (including fine cocktails) near Moore Square in downtown Raleigh. Since 1997.

venue.title: B.N. Duke Auditorium, NCCU
venue.blurb: Named for Benjamin Newton Duke and built in 1937, the B.N. Duke Auditorium hosts performers coming to North Carolina Central University (NCCU). It is listed on the National Registry of Historic Places.

venue.title: Ackland Art Museum
venue.blurb: The Ackland features the University of North Carolina's student art projects, special exhibits and permanent display of the university's collection European masters, treasures from ancient Greece and Rome, and examples of the modern and the post-modern. Main-floor spaces will be transformed by photographs, video and oral projects, an auditorium, performance art and strange installations, depending on the current exhibit. Upstairs are not-to-miss collections of Asian art and North Carolina pottery.

venue.title: Lucha Tigre
venue.blurb: Lucha Tigre means “fighting tiger,” and the fusion of Mexican and Asian cuisines suggests ideas for other interesting clashes of culture: Luchador vs. Samurai? Tiger vs Luchador? Well, why not? Lucha’s fresh, spicy cuisine also mixes the food of two continents with such delights as Kung Pao tacos and Peruvian Shrimp with Wasabi Mashed Potatoes. There are plenty of options for vegetarians, vegans, and everybody else.Weekdays 11:30 am – 2:30 pm, 5 pm-12 pmWeekends 12 am - 4 pm brunch, dinner until 12 pm

venue.title: Memorial Hall, UNC
venue.blurb: The original Memorial Hall was built in 1883 to accommodate the UNC’s public occasions and basketball games. In 1929 it was declared unsafe and was rebuilt with fewer towers and turrets, and then renovated completely in the early 2000s. Memorial Hall retains a sense of history and intimacy, though it now seats over 1,400 people, and has elevators, climate control, ramps, and more backstage space.Ticket prices vary between orchestra and balcony, but all seats enjoy good sight lines and acoustics.Refreshments, including wine and beer, are available in the lobby.

venue.title: Motorco Music Hall
venue.blurb: Motorco is an all-ages club with indoor and patio seating, a full bar and an attached restaurant that serves an array of international street food, including vegetarian and vegan items. The main performance area accommodates 450, with riser seating, a few bistro tables, and room to stand or dance. Events vary from live bluegrass to hip hop, film showings, community gatherings and podcasts.

venue.title: Stewart Theatre, NCSU
venue.blurb: The recently-refurbished Stewart Theatre seats 759 people, with excellent sight-lines and acoustics. An adjacent bistro serves full meals, wine, and beer before performances. There is nearby free parking after 5 PM.

venue.title: Pinhook
venue.blurb: Casual whiskey bar is a central hub for local punks and performing bands, DJs, hip-hop artists and open-mic hounds. Karaoke & trivia.

venue.title: Nightlight
venue.blurb: Remember the Skylight Exchange on Rosemary Street? Though the space no longer moonlights as a bookstore, the stage at Nightlight prolongs the building's life as a place of relevance for the Southeast's music scene.

venue.title: The ArtsCenter
venue.blurb: Plays, exhibits, storytelling, galleries, movement and dance classes, art school, a potter's wheel. For 35-plus years The ArtsCenter in Carrboro has been a temple to the artistic and creative tendencies of the Town of Carrboro. World-best performers and local theater take the Wynn and West End Theater stages, which are also available to rent.

venue.title: Oasis at Carr Mill
venue.blurb: Oasis is a unique tea house and coffee shop in Carr Mill Mall. A beautiful exotic setting with pillows on the floor, plants that create a tropical effect and transient music. Oasis often has guest speakers and musicians from all over the world give free performances.

venue.title: Durham Performing Arts Center
venue.blurb: The Durham Performing Arts Center offers over 200 performances each year. DPAC offers the best seating and live entertainment experience to all its guests.

venue.title: Cat's Cradle Back Room
venue.blurb: A bar and balcony enhance the Back Room's prime draw: top-gear performers booked by the Cradle. The build-out of the Back Room behind the Cradle's main theater at 300 East Main (a building which also houses Amante Pizza, Yesteryears Brewery, the ArtsCenter and WCOM's community radio studio) expanded Cat's Cradle's delivery of great music to Carrboro.

venue.title: The Regulator Bookshop
venue.blurb: Standing at the ever-ready to supply the literary thirsts of Duke students and Ninth Street strollers, this "small and improbable bookstore" began life in December of the bicentennial. By its own record, the first customer was Agnes Birkhead, Court stenographer of the Scopes Monkey Trial.

venue.title: The Baxter Arcade
venue.blurb: The "barcade" craze has tapped into the nostalgia and fun-spirits of adult Gen-X and Gen-Y'ers, and the Baxter Arcade delivers on all the necessary levels. Video arcade games, pinball machines, local drafts, cocktails, a large screen and a dance floor make the Baxter a Palladium for Carrboro hipsters and Chapel Hill party people.

venue.title: Kings
venue.blurb: One of Raleigh's musical landmarks, Kings books alternative rock and other musical acts, and also stand-up comedy and game nights, and The Great Cover-Up, a hugely popular battle of the cover bands. Full-sized stage and full bar. Neptune's is a separate bar below Kings with arcade games, with DJ nights and some live acts.

venue.title: Koka Booth Amphitheatre
venue.blurb: Outdoor venue at the edge of Symphony Lake owned by the Town of Cary. Formerly the Amphitheatre at Regency Park, in 2004 it was renamed for Koka Booth, a former mayor of the Town of Cary.

venue.title: The Clean Machine
venue.blurb: Since 1972, The Clean Machine has made Carrboro the bicycle capital of North Carolina. Locally owned, with a personable, dedicated staff who are all cycling enthusiasts, The Clean Machine, and its sister stores – The Bicycle Chain, located on Franklin Street in Chapel Hill as well as in Durham, Apex, and Raleigh – focus on encouraging a healthy lifestyle, engaging with the community, and providing long-term, consistent, excellent service.

venue.title: Wilson Park
venue.blurb: Just off Greensboro Street, this 8.5 acre park near downtown Carrboro features lighted tennis courts and a youth baseball field (also lighted) grills and picnic tables, a pavilion, and access to the Bolin Creek Trailway and Adams Tract Urban Forest Area.

venue.title: Carolina North Forest
venue.blurb: For more than 30 years Carolina North Forest, to use the words of UNC Facilities Services, "has offered the University, Chapel Hill and Carrboro communities a tranquil natural oasis in which to recreate, relax, and enjoy a respite from the area’s ever-changing urban landscape."At least 250 acres — one third of this tranquil oasis — is portioned for grading and development into a proposed satellite campus for the University of North Carolina.

venue.title: McIntyre's Books
venue.blurb: Independent bookstore since 1989, opened by Keebe Fitch. McIntyre’s Books sells with an emphasis on cooking, gardening, mystery and local authors. Boasts one of the largest author events programs in the South.

venue.title: Greensboro Coliseum
venue.blurb: Home of the UNC-Greensboro Spartans. Opened in 1959, Greensboro Coliseum has a truly historic role hosting large-scale sports and entertainment events in the Midcoast region. from The Monkees (with opener Jimi Hendrix). Long history as site of the Atlantic Coast Conference Basketball Tournament was interrupted in 2016 due to controversy over North Carolina's bathroom laws. Also home to the NBA D-League Greensboro Swarm, and hosting events at Odeon Theatre, White Oak Amphitheatre, Greensboro Aquatic Center and the ACC Hall of Champions.

venue.title: North Carolina Museum of Art
venue.blurb: Collection established out of 1947 appropriation of $1 million. Current building on Blue Ridge Road opened in 1983 with major West Building expansion completed in 2010. Permanent works include 30 bronzes by sculptor Rodin. Outdoor movies, educational events, galleries and special exhibits.

venue.title: Carrboro Farmers' Market
venue.blurb: Since 1977, The Carrboro Farmer’s Market represents the best that our locale has to offer in home grown and handmade products. Here, you can find homemade soaps, handmade jewelry, or perhaps a family-perfected Bloody Mary mix, and, of course, the finest in home grown and farm raised foods. The Market is operated by farmers and artisans within a 50-mile radius. In fact, according to the market’s website (link below), most of the food comes from within 25 miles. Rules of the market require that the producers operate their own booths, which offers the opportunity to meet people from the area and learn about what goes into their products. There are generally food trucks on location, and the Farmer’s Market operates year-round. Though it is a fun time outdoors, no dogs are allowed.

venue.title: Global Breath Studio
venue.blurb: Yoga and movement studio in downtown Durham.

venue.title: Carroll Middle School
venue.blurb: Carroll Leadership in Technology Magnet Middle School is a Grades 6-8 school in Wake County Public School System.

venue.title: Williams Field at Jack Katz Stadium
Meredith Athletic Field and Track Complex
Shakori Hills
venue.blurb: The South's little Woodstock in Chatham County, N.C. A converted farm with tents and stages for twice-annual Grassroots music festival and special events.

venue.title: Durham Rescue Mission
venue.blurb: The Durham Rescue Mission is Durham’s oldest and largest long-term shelter, the Durham Rescue Mission currently serves 400 men, women and children a day, 365 days a year throughout the Triangle by providing safe shelter, addiction recovery programs and much more.

venue.title: Ponysaurus Brewing Company
venue.blurb: Ponysaurus Brewing Company is a brewery and bar in downtown Durham that plays all the games on multiple televisions and holds scheduled tours of their brewery.

venue.title: Duke Energy Center for the Performing Arts
Rubenstein Arts Center
venue.blurb: "The Ruby" is a center for Duke's art production, from dance to studio art. It was opened in 2018 and sits not far from the Sarah P. Duke Gardens.

venue.title: Fearrington Village
venue.blurb: Located on a former dairy farm and laid out like a village center, Fearrington Village holds The Fearrington House Inn and Restaurant, The Spa at Fearrington, McIntyre’s Books, Dovecote Style, The Belted Goat deli, Roost beer garden and special events productions.

venue.title: Chapel Hill Public Library
venue.blurb: Host of educational and community events, with a small café and bookstore as well as, of course, the oboks.

venue.title: McKimmon Center for Extension and Continuing Education
venue.blurb: Adult education center on NC State University campus.

venue.title: Varsity Theatre
venue.blurb: The theater has adapted to new films and new audiences and a new Franklin Street while maintaining a vintage feel and treasured place in the community.

venue.title: Wheels Fun Park
venue.blurb: Fun for families and friends who want to roller skate, drive go karts, play mini golf and more.

venue.title: Lumina Theater
venue.blurb: Independent Chapel Hill movie theater, showing first-run films in five theaters.

venue.title: Uptown Bar and Lounge
venue.blurb: Uptown dance club, night club and lounge in downtown Durham.

venue.title: UNC Friday Center for Continuing Education
North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences
Durham Central Park
venue.blurb: Five acres of gardens, walkways, lawns, and attractions, plus a large (9,000-ft square) covered Pavilion for gatherings and performances. Central Park is host to Farmer’s Markets and food truck rodeos, live music, and film showings, and is the annual site for Durham’s Earth Day Festival.In addition to the Pavilion, Central Park is home to a skate park, playground, and sculptures.

venue.title: Sonja Haynes Stone Center for Black Culture and History
Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University
Kings & Neptunes
venue.blurb: Two clubs, one address

venue.title: The Northside District
venue.blurb: Sells alcohol

venue.title: Paperhand Puppet Intervention Studio
venue.blurb: Based in Carrboro, this groundbreaking troupe performs with pageantry, giant puppets, masks, stilts, shadow plays and live music. Each year’s program tells a different story about the world we share with other living beings, often drawing on folklore and mythology for its themes. Their shows are always family-friendly and often inspirational.

venue.title: James and Susan Moeser Auditorium in Hill Hall
